I'm not sure what disturbs me more, the way the article was written in regards to EMS or some of the comments that somehow attribute this crime to the profession and generalize the professionals within the industry. Most likely I assume individuals have been influenced by the writers depiction of the EMS profession.
Having been a NYC Paramedic for 20 years and having worked in some of NYC most impoverished communities I can attest that the job does not cause you to murder your wife for insurance proceeds. There is no dark subculture, no secret handshakes or fraternity to cover up crimes committed by those within our ranks. Most EMS workers that have been doing this for any length of time and have worked in challenging areas have testified in court enough times to realize that there is no perfect crime and it sure does not pay.
Lastly, most readers can rest assure that they are safe to call 911 without fearing that the responding medic may somehow cause them harm. Most of us don't do this for the money, you'd be shocked to hear the pay and the poor pension that comes with the job, we do this mostly because we believe in our profession and care about the public. We don't deserve special treatment, but some respect for what we do would be nice.

My aunt was being treated in a Gundersen Lutheran clinic in LaCrosse, WI where they were the exemplar of end of life discussion, known as "advance directives" that were demonized as "death panels." My cousin's family had the benefit of nearly a decade of preparation as her dementia progressed. When the end came they knew her wishes and were at peace with abiding by her directives. My mother, who lived in another state, did not have such clear directives and this led to a week of unnecessary medical procedures as well as continued second-guessing by non-siblings.

My local member of congress was Chair of the Medicare Subcommittee. I stood outside town hall meetings open to all in late summer of 2009 where he, and several dozen medical professionals, were demonized for promoting "death panels." At the time I was cofounder of a medical device startup, had read and understood much of the ACA, and knew the protocols to which it referred and the benefits for patients and families.

A stem cell transplant with a 70% success rate is hardly a Hail Mary pass. Sounds to me like it was the right choice for this particular family even though their relative turned out to be on the wrong side of the numbers. (I speak from experience here.)

Many good points are raised here. However, where Mr. Bruni states: " if we’re concerned about all working women, we have to talk about child care, flexible hours, paid leave... " - and we do indeed have to look at those elements of infrastructure - I would replace "women" with "families." Invariably, we must be concerned with impacts on children, spouses, siblings, aging parents - of both genders. Moreover, let's not forget that we continue to socialize our girls differently (those gender stereotypes / so-called choices), as we occupy their brains with notions of prettiness over competence, pleasing over questioning, following over leading, and we do so by praising and valuing certain behaviors over others.

As for those who say this is "just" an issue for working mothers, I recall a Times article by Stephanie Coontz (in 2012) that provided more context than the usual stream of stats. I quote: "... a 2010 Catalyst survey found that female M.B.A.’s were paid an average of $4,600 less than men in starting salaries and continue to be outpaced by men in rank and salary growth throughout their careers, even if they remain childless."

I totally agree with Peggy's comment. Parents can wind up doing the homework, book report or science fair projects which really doesn't help the student. Then there are the "helicopter parents" who hover over both child and teacher.
The best kind of support that worked for my students was when parents showed respect for education, spent time with their children going to museums, zoos, etc., and engaged them in conversation and opened them up to current events. There should also be a partnership between parent and teacher. When students see that relationship, they respect the teacher, school and are more prone to want to do well.
Some parents don't have any control over their children. They can beg them to behave, study, and do their homework, but to no avail. Parents need support too and the schools should work with them and give them the tools they need. A child's success is more than a passing test score, it's also about emotional and social growth. But that can't be measured by a standardized test.

I work with children every day in school. The ones who make the most progress and are able to benefit from instruction are the ones whose parents 1) are physically present in their children's lives; 2) set clear rules and limits for children, for example a set bedtime; 3) provide a place, a time, and an expectation for homework to be completed; 4) make sure their child gets to school every day, on time; and 5) discuss the impact of their current learning on their future education and career. I have seen every one of these principles broken by parents and the effect on the children is difficult to witness. It's hard to see a child who longs for his absent father; another comes to school chaotic and exhausted because there are no set rules at home; another child is motivated to succeed but never, ever returns his homework; and still another missed two weeks of school to take part in a wedding in Mexico and lost weeks of instruction as she re-adjusted to school.

That's what parental involvement is - and it makes one heck of a difference for kids. I don't need a scientific study to prove it - it's proved every day in every school.

This issue is so complicated. I applaud Mr. Bruni's admiration of his sister in how she fills multiple roles with finesse, effectiveness and humor. What gets difficult is the mix of two different issues: the need for women to have equal pay, deservedly so, and the need to parent alongside of employment. If our society recognized that parenting is a top priority and should be encompassed within a parent's employment role with the deepest respect, perhaps the pay issue would become moot. I think there are many people who feel pressured to sacrifice parenting time because they feel that they have to please employers or the corporate culture with availability in order to be viewed as successful or worthy of advancement. It is important for mothers to be able  to mold their jobs or careers around their parenting preferences and to advocate for ways to be engaged in their employment settings on their terms. This means  not only demanding equal pay but insisting that advancement be determined on merits that are not always related to how much time has been put into the job but on competency and potential for growth.Hopefully, more creative options will continue to emerge as mothers demand more flexible work arrangements that recognize part-time work schedules, parenting commitments, knowledge gained by parenting, and shared job positions, with commensurate rewards for experiences accrued from such endeavors.
